author: sky.cactus
content: <@!211091239112671234> Is it your belief that block processing time or resource requirements is non-linear with gas? (for after the call)

author: holiman
content: I think resource requirements are linear with gas. But one transaction burning 1M gas is worse than 5 txs burning 1M gas, because the journal is never reset. If we exec 5 txs, we reset the journal between each. So if we were to execute an extremely large transaction, we might hit new never-seen-before memory issues, in areas we haven't really considered problematic before. Similarly, executing a very large block (even if it is spread out over many txs), makes the 'set of data to commit' to the trie very large. This set is kept in memory, and must at some point be shoved to the db. If refunds are used: refunds are actually also writes, from a db perspective. So without refunds, we do one write. If a refund is used, it's in practice giving a stipend for the second write. So basically, the risk as I see it is that the set of stuff to write becomes too large, which causes problem with IO and might cause problem with the refcounting in-memory pruner. All of these this are pretty hard to explain, because what I'm talking about is really geth internals. However, I would suppose that other nodes also would have similar issues with large blocks.
